title: Momentum builds for law change following Bob Higgins child sexual abuse case
text:
A campaign to include child sexual abuse among those “serious crimes” for which suspects can be retried gathered momentum on Monday with the backing of former footballers and a series of charities.

The Daily Telegraph revealed on Monday the extent to which Bob Higgins, the paedophile former Southampton coach, is now alleged to have abused young footballers even after the authorities were first alerted to concerns about his behaviour in 1989.

A total of 95 people have come forward, of which 13 were after 1989, but the original six Southampton players who gave statements to the police could not be part of the trial that resulted in Higgins’ conviction in May for indecently assaulting 23 boys between 1971 and 1996.

This is because they are subject to the ‘double jeopardy’ rule that prevents a suspect being tried twice for the same crime. Higgins was found not guilty of one count of indecent assault in 1992 and the Crown Prosecution Service did not present evidence in the other cases and a not guilty verdict was recorded. Double jeopardy exceptions for compelling new evidence are only made in 30 serious crimes and Dean Radford, who first came forward to allege abuse by Higgins in 1989, has launched a petition to include child sex abuse among those “serious crimes” that could be retried.
